title: Study on Solid Waste Burning in Three Communities
text: Investigate factors influencing household solid waste quantities and disposal by burning.

title: Study on Solid Waste Burning in Three Communities
text: Investigate factors influencing household solid waste quantities and disposal by burning.

title: Study on Solid Waste Burning in Three Communities
text:
Method

Collected solid waste from 150 households over a week.
Measured waste quantities on a weighing scale (fractions of kg).
Conducted waste characterisation (organic, plastic, paper, others).
Assessed normality using QQ plots.
Applied Poisson regression to identify contextual factors associated with differences in waste quantities.

Example contextual factors considered:

Household size

Income level

Presence of children

Frequency of collection

Access to bins
Results

Table 1: Poisson regression results showing factors associated with household solid waste quantities (Significant P values in bold)



Variable
Estimate
Std. Error

0.026

title: Study on Solid Waste Burning in Three Communities
text:
Interpretation:
Household size: Larger households produce significantly more waste (p = 0.001).
Access to bins: Households with bin access produce less waste, likely due to reduced burning (p = 0.026).
Other factors (income, children) show weaker associations.

title: Study on Solid Waste Burning in Three Communities
text:
Conclusion and Policy Implications
Larger households generate more solid waste, and limited bin access increases the likelihood of burning waste. Policy makers should improve access to household or community bins, especially in high-density areas, promote regular waste collection services to prevent accumulation, and educate communities on safe disposal methods to reduce burning and associated health risks. Interventions can also target households producing the most waste based on size or composition. Poisson regression provides a data-driven basis for prioritising interventions and allocating resources.

title: Social Media Marketing and Digital Banking Adoption: A K-Means Clustering Approach
text:
The growth of digital banking has reshaped how customers interact with financial services. Social media marketing (SMM) has become one of the most influential tools for promoting digital banking services, especially among young adults.
Understanding how customer engagement on social media relates to their adoption of digital banking can help financial institutions improve outreach strategies.
Machine learning, particularly K-means clustering, offers an effective way to uncover hidden patterns in customer data. This method groups individuals with similar characteristics without requiring predefined categories.

title: Social Media Marketing and Digital Banking Adoption: A K-Means Clustering Approach
text:
The growth of digital banking has reshaped how customers interact with financial services. Social media marketing (SMM) has become one of the most influential tools for promoting digital banking services, especially among young adults.
Understanding how customer engagement on social media relates to their adoption of digital banking can help financial institutions improve outreach strategies.
Machine learning, particularly K-means clustering, offers an effective way to uncover hidden patterns in customer data. This method groups individuals with similar characteristics without requiring predefined categories.

title: Social Media Marketing and Digital Banking Adoption: A K-Means Clustering Approach
text:
Goal
To identify clusters of digital banking users based on their engagement with social media marketing activities and their level of digital banking adoption.

title: Social Media Marketing and Digital Banking Adoption: A K-Means Clustering Approach
text:
Methods

Data were collected from 1000 participants through an online survey assessing:
Frequency of social media use (1‚Äì5 scale)
Engagement with bank advertisements (1‚Äì5 scale)
Trust in digital banking (1‚Äì5 scale)
Number of digital banking features used (0‚Äì10)
Demographic data (age group, gender, education)

The K-means clustering algorithm was applied to the numeric variables to group respondents into distinct behavioural clusters.
K-means is an unsupervised machine learning method that minimises within-cluster variation and maximises between-cluster differences.

title: Social Media Marketing and Digital Banking Adoption: A K-Means Clustering Approach
text:
Results
Three main clusters were identified (k = 3):











Cluster
Description
Mean Social Media Engagement
Mean Trust Score
Mean Features Used
Size (n)




1
Passive Users
2.1
2.5
1.3
85


2
Moderate Engagers
3.4
3.7
4.6
95


3
Active Digital Adopters
4.6
4.8
8.9
70



Cluster 1 users showed low interaction with social media marketing and limited digital banking use.
Cluster 2 displayed moderate engagement and moderate use of digital features.
Cluster 3 represented highly engaged users who actively use multiple digital banking features and express strong trust in digital banking.
The graphical representation in Figure¬†1 shows how respondents were grouped by the K-means algorithm.








Figure¬†1: Distribution of K-means clusters of digital banking users based on social media marketing engagement

title: Social Media Marketing and Digital Banking Adoption: A K-Means Clustering Approach
text:
Interpretation
The clustering shows clear differences between passive, moderate, and active users. Active digital adopters display both high social media activity and extensive use of digital banking features, suggesting that social media marketing strongly relates to digital engagement behaviour.
This segmentation can guide targeted communication strategies:

Cluster 1: awareness campaigns to build trust
Cluster 2: nudges to deepen feature use
Cluster 3: loyalty programmes to maintain engagement

title: Assessment of Antibiotic Residues and Microbial Quality Chicken
text: Antibiotics are frequently used in poultry production to prevent disease and enhance growth. Poor handling of poultry products can lead to contamination and the presence of antibiotic residues in meat.

title: Assessment of Antibiotic Residues and Microbial Quality Chicken
text: Antibiotics are frequently used in poultry production to prevent disease and enhance growth. Poor handling of poultry products can lead to contamination and the presence of antibiotic residues in meat.

title: Assessment of Antibiotic Residues and Microbial Quality Chicken
text:
Goal
The purpose of this study was to examine microbial contamination and antibiotic residues in chicken samples collected from three markets, labelled A, B, and C.

title: Assessment of Antibiotic Residues and Microbial Quality Chicken
text:
Method
Fifteen samples (five from each market) were transported at 4 ¬∞C to the microbiology laboratory. The samples were tested for Escherichia coli, Salmonella spp., and Staphylococcus aureus. All 15 samples were positive for E. coli, while Salmonella and Staphylococcus were not detected.

title: Assessment of Antibiotic Residues and Microbial Quality Chicken
text:
Antibiotic Residue Analysis
Another set of analyses focused on quantifying four antibiotics: Amoxicillin, Sulfamethoxazole, Ciprofloxacin, and Trimethoprim using HPLC. Method validation followed standard analytical guidelines for precision and accuracy.

title: Assessment of Antibiotic Residues and Microbial Quality Chicken
text:
Principal Component Analysis
To explore relationships among antibiotic residues, a Principal Component Analysis (PCA) was performed. The PCA revealed that Amoxicillin contributed most to the first component, while Ciprofloxacin and Trimethoprim had higher loadings on the second component, indicating differences in residue behaviour across markets.
The results are presented in Figure¬†1








Figure¬†1: PCA Variable Correlation Plot

title: Assessment of Antibiotic Residues and Microbial Quality Chicken
section: Comparison of Residue Levels Before and After Cooking
text:
Comparison of Residue Levels Before and After Cooking
To test whether cooking reduced antibiotic residues, samples from each market were analysed before and after heat treatment.
Table 1. Mean antibiotic residue concentrations (¬µg/kg) before and after cooking in chicken samples from three anonymised markets

‚Äì1.4 ‚Äì 2.7
0.47



Significant p-values in bold

title: Assessment of Antibiotic Residues and Microbial Quality Chicken
text:
Interpretation
Cooking significantly reduced levels of amoxicillin and sulfamethoxazole, as indicated by p-values below 0.05. The changes in ciprofloxacin and trimethoprim concentrations were not statistically significant. These results suggest that while cooking helps lower antibiotic residues, it may not eliminate them completely.

title: Assessment of Antibiotic Residues and Microbial Quality Chicken
text:
Conclusion
Findings indicate that poultry products sold in the three markets contained measurable antibiotic residues and microbial contamination. The results highlight the need for better awareness on safe antibiotic use and handling of poultry products.

title: Study on Goat Disease Prevalence in Three Cities of Malawi
text: Compare the prevalence of a pig disease across three cities: Blantyre, Lilongwe, and Mzuzu.

title: Study on Goat Disease Prevalence in Three Cities of Malawi
text: Compare the prevalence of a pig disease across three cities: Blantyre, Lilongwe, and Mzuzu.

title: Study on Goat Disease Prevalence in Three Cities of Malawi
text:
Method

Cross-sectional survey of pig farms in the three cities.
Calculated prevalence (%) for each farm
Conducted one-way ANOVA to test for differences in mean prevalence
Applied Tukey post-hoc test when ANOVA indicated significant differences.

title: Study on Goat Disease Prevalence in Three Cities of Malawi
text:
Results
A one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA) was conducted to compare the mean prevalence of the disease across the three cities. When a significant difference was detected, pairwise comparisons were performed using Tukey‚Äôs post-hoc test. The results are presented in Table 1.
Table 1: One-way ANOVA comparing mean prevalence of the disease across Blantyre, Lilongwe, and Mzuzu



Source of Variation
SS
df

F
p-value

0.007


Within Cities
430.5

15.94




Total
575.7
29

title: Study on Goat Disease Prevalence in Three Cities of Malawi
text:
Interpretation

The ANOVA shows a statistically significant difference in mean disease prevalence among the three cities (p = 0.007)

This indicates that at least one city differs from the others in terms of average prevalence.

title: Study on Goat Disease Prevalence in Three Cities of Malawi
text:
Turkey
Since the ANOVA results showed a significant difference in disease prevalence across the three cities, Tukey‚Äôs post-hoc test was carried out to identify which pairs of cities differed significantly. The results are presented in Table 2.
Table 2: Tukey‚Äôs post-hoc pairwise comparison of mean disease prevalence among Blantyre, Lilongwe, and Mzuzu



Comparison
Mean Difference

-7.9 ‚Äì 1.3
0.17

title: Study on Goat Disease Prevalence in Three Cities of Malawi
text:
Interpretation

Blantyre vs Lilongwe: Significant difference (p = 0.014); Blantyre has higher mean prevalence by 6.5%.
Blantyre vs Mzuzu: Not significant (p = 0.18); mean difference of 3.2% is not statistically meaningful.
Lilongwe vs Mzuzu: Not significant (p = 0.17); mean difference of -3.3% is not statistically meaningful.

title: Study on Goat Disease Prevalence in Three Cities of Malawi
text:
Conclusion

The overall prevalence of the pig disease differs significantly among the three cities.
Blantyre has significantly higher prevalence compared to Lilongwe, while differences with Mzuzu are not statistically significant.
This suggests that targeted interventions may be needed in Blantyre to control the disease.

title: Study on Infrastructure Functionality in Rural Communities
text: Identify factors affecting the functionality of infrastructure in rural communities.

title: Study on Infrastructure Functionality in Rural Communities
text: Identify factors affecting the functionality of infrastructure in rural communities.

title: Study on Infrastructure Functionality in Rural Communities
text:
Method

Survey data collected using a structured questionnaire adapted from public tools.
Created a binary outcome variable for functionality (functional vs non-functional).
Conducted data cleaning, variable recoding, and multivariate binary logistic regression.

title: Study on Infrastructure Functionality in Rural Communities
text:
Results
A multivariable binary logistic regression identified several factors significantly associated with functionality. The results are presented in Table 1.
Table 1: Multivariable binary logistic regression showing factors associated with borehole functionality in rural Karonga (Significant P values in bold)










Variable
Coefficient
p-value
Odds Ratio
95% CI (OR)




Maintenance frequency

title: Study on Infrastructure Functionality in Rural Communities
text:
Interpretation of Results:

Maintenance frequency: Regular maintenance significantly increases the odds of functionality (OR = 1.91, 95% CI: 1.06‚Äì3.45, p = 0.03), meaning units with consistent maintenance are 91% more likely to remain functional.

Distance to service point: Longer distance shows a non-significant negative effect (OR = 0.66, 95% CI: 0.41‚Äì1.05, p = 0.08), suggesting a possible decrease in functionality but not statistically confirmed.

Community management: Strong management significantly improves functionality (OR = 2.18, 95% CI: 1.20‚Äì3.95, p = 0.01), more than doubling the likelihood of operational infrastructure.

Monetary contribution: Units with higher community monetary support have significantly increased functionality (OR = 1.73, 95% CI: 1.02‚Äì2.95, p = 0.04).

Technical support: Presence of technical support shows a positive but non-significant effect (OR = 1.62, 95% CI: 0.90‚Äì2.91, p = 0.12).

title: Study on Infrastructure Functionality in Rural Communities
text:
Conclusion:
Maintenance frequency, community management, and monetary contribution are statistically significant predictors of infrastructure functionality.Distance to service point and technical support may influence outcomes, but their effects are not statistically confirmed.
Focus on regular maintenance, strong management, and community contributions to improve operational results.

title: Package prices
text:
We will choose the package together. If you need more advanced tests later, we can upgrade easily..
To recommend the best package for your study, I just need a few details:

title: Ethics Policy
text:
Ethical conduct is central to all our activities. This policy explains our commitment to honesty, integrity, and responsibility in every service we provide.
Key Issues include

All work is carried out transparently and responsibly.
Informed consent is obtained where applicable before collecting any data.
Conflicts of interest are identified and managed proactively.
All analyses, reports, and client interactions follow professional and ethical standards.
This ensures clients can trust the accuracy, fairness, and integrity of our services.

title: Confidentiality Policy
text:
We protect all information shared with us. Our approach ensures:

No other persone can access your sensitive data.
No confidential information is disclosed externally without permission.
Staff are trained to handle confidential information responsibly.
Clients can share information knowing it will remain private.
Maintaining confidentiality builds trust and supports strong relationships.

title: Data Management Policy
text:
Proper handling of data is essential to provide reliable and secure services. This policy outlines how we organise, protect, and maintain data throughout its lifecycle. Our commitments include:

Data is stored securely with controlled access to prevent unauthorized use.
Regular backups are performed to prevent accidental loss.
Data retention schedules are followed to keep information only as long as necessary.
When data is no longer required, it is securely deleted.
All procedures ensure data integrity, reliability, and security.

title: Data Analysis Lab: Where Data Meets Insight
text:
We are a team of data analysis experts who turn complex data into clear, actionable insights using the power of R statistical software.
 # We help students get accurate and well-presented data analysis for their research projects, making it easier for their work to be accepted by their universities.{.text-center}



We envision a future where every student can complete their research confidently, supported by accurate and reliable data analysis.


We are aware that students need to be taken through the data science cycle whereby their data is cleaned, visualised and analysed.
To fill that gap, our team helps students by providing the following:



Data Cleaning
Preparing and validating your data for analysis with meticulous attention to detail


Data Visualisation
Creating insightful charts and interactive dashboards that tell compelling stories


Data Analysis
Applying statistical methods and data science techniques to extract meaningful insights

title: The Extent of solid waste burning in Blantyre, Malawi
text: In Blantyre, Malawi, Solid waste burning has become a necessary waste management strategy to reduce waste volume in areas with limited solid waste collection(Nagpure, Ramaswami, and Russell 2015) . Waste burning is a source of particulate matter emissions that cause respiratory infection (Ramadan, Rachman, and Matsumoto 2022) . However, researchers have not studied waste burning at either the city or intra-city scale in Malawi. There is an emerging literature addressing onsite waste disposal methods in Malawian cities, including Lilongwe [Kalonde et al. (2023)](Ndala and Ndala, n.d.). However, disposal methods in other Malawian cities, including Blantyre, Mzuzu and Zomba are under-studied. ¬†Studying Open waste burning will generate data that can enable the local authorities to design location-specific interventions that would address the issue.

title: The Extent of solid waste burning in Blantyre, Malawi
text: In Blantyre, Malawi, Solid waste burning has become a necessary waste management strategy to reduce waste volume in areas with limited solid waste collection(Nagpure, Ramaswami, and Russell 2015) . Waste burning is a source of particulate matter emissions that cause respiratory infection (Ramadan, Rachman, and Matsumoto 2022) . However, researchers have not studied waste burning at either the city or intra-city scale in Malawi. There is an emerging literature addressing onsite waste disposal methods in Malawian cities, including Lilongwe [Kalonde et al. (2023)](Ndala and Ndala, n.d.). However, disposal methods in other Malawian cities, including Blantyre, Mzuzu and Zomba are under-studied. ¬†Studying Open waste burning will generate data that can enable the local authorities to design location-specific interventions that would address the issue.

title: Study on Similarity of Microbial Communities Across Vegetables, Soil, and Fertiliser Sources
text: Examine the similarity of microbial communities in three sample sources: vegetables, farm soil, and fertiliser, to understand how microbial populations overlap.

title: Study on Similarity of Microbial Communities Across Vegetables, Soil, and Fertiliser Sources
text: Examine the similarity of microbial communities in three sample sources: vegetables, farm soil, and fertiliser, to understand how microbial populations overlap.

title: Study on Similarity of Microbial Communities Across Vegetables, Soil, and Fertiliser Sources
text:
Method

Samples collected from vegetable surfaces, adjacent soil, and fertiliser.
Microbial communities characterised using standard laboratory methods.
Jaccard similarity index calculated for all pairwise combinations to measure community overlap.
Statistical significance evaluated with bootstrapped confidence intervals (95% CI) and p-values.

title: Study on Similarity of Microbial Communities Across Vegetables, Soil, and Fertiliser Sources
text:
Results
Table 1 presents the mean Jaccard Index values representing microbial similarity between vegetables, soil, and fertiliser samples. The 95% confidence intervals indicate the precision of the estimated similarity, while the p-values show the statistical significance of differences observed between source pairs. Significant associations (p < 0.05) suggest a meaningful overlap in microbial communities between those sources.
Table 1: Similarity of microbial communities across sample sources based on the Jaccard Index









Source Pair
Mean Jaccard Index
95% CI
p-value




Vegetables ‚Äì Soil

Soil ‚Äì Fertiliser
0.29

0.08

title: Study on Similarity of Microbial Communities Across Vegetables, Soil, and Fertiliser Sources
text:
Interpretation of Results:

Vegetables ‚Äì Soil: Mean Jaccard index = 0.42 (95% CI: 0.35‚Äì0.49, p = 0.01) indicates a significant overlap of microbial communities between vegetables and the soil. This suggests that soil contributes substantially to the microbial populations found on vegetables.
Vegetables ‚Äì Fertiliser: Mean Jaccard index = 0.31 (95% CI: 0.25‚Äì0.38, p = 0.02) shows significant similarity, indicating that fertiliser may also be a source of microbes on vegetables, though to a lesser extent than soil.
Soil ‚Äì Fertiliser: Mean Jaccard index = 0.29 (95% CI: 0.22‚Äì0.36, p = 0.08) is not statistically significant, suggesting that microbial communities in soil and fertiliser are less similar and differences may be due to random variation.

title: Study on Similarity of Microbial Communities Across Vegetables, Soil, and Fertiliser Sources
text:
Conclusion

The microbial communities on vegetables share significant similarities with both soil and fertiliser, highlighting potential routes for microbial transfer.
Soil appears to be the primary source, followed by fertiliser.
Understanding these overlaps can guide interventions for microbial management in farming practices.

title: Impact of a Behaviour Change Communication Intervention on Cybersecurity Awareness
text:
Cybersecurity awareness remains a growing concern as more people rely on digital tools for financial transactions, communication, and information access. Many users lack knowledge on identifying phishing attempts, creating strong passwords, and verifying the authenticity of online content. Behaviour Change Communication (BCC) interventions that combine mass media and social engagement can play a key role in addressing these gaps.
This report presents the results of a BCC intervention that used radio programmes and online engagement to promote safe cybersecurity practices. The objectives were to:

Assess the level of audience engagement through radio and social media interactions.
Measure the change in cybersecurity knowledge following exposure to the intervention using a differences-in-differences approach.

title: Impact of a Behaviour Change Communication Intervention on Cybersecurity Awareness
text:
Cybersecurity awareness remains a growing concern as more people rely on digital tools for financial transactions, communication, and information access. Many users lack knowledge on identifying phishing attempts, creating strong passwords, and verifying the authenticity of online content. Behaviour Change Communication (BCC) interventions that combine mass media and social engagement can play a key role in addressing these gaps.
This report presents the results of a BCC intervention that used radio programmes and online engagement to promote safe cybersecurity practices. The objectives were to:

Assess the level of audience engagement through radio and social media interactions.
Measure the change in cybersecurity knowledge following exposure to the intervention using a differences-in-differences approach.

title: Impact of a Behaviour Change Communication Intervention on Cybersecurity Awareness
text:
Description of the Intervention
The intervention ran for three months and targeted adult listeners in selected districts. Weekly 30-minute radio call-in programmes were broadcast, focusing on topics such as detecting phishing links, setting secure passwords, updating software, and avoiding scams.
Each episode encouraged listeners to ask questions by calling during live sessions or sending messages through Facebook, SMS, or WhatsApp. The radio programme was supported by:

Short radio spots that repeated key messages throughout the week.
Facebook posts summarising each episode.
SMS and WhatsApp tips sent to subscribers after every broadcast.

A call log system captured all engagements across platforms to understand audience participation and the main cybersecurity issues raised.

title: Impact of a Behaviour Change Communication Intervention on Cybersecurity Awareness
text:
Engagement Tracking
During the campaign, all incoming calls and messages were recorded. The records captured the channel, time, and key phrases mentioned. Table 1 presents a sample of entries from the call log.
Table 1: Sample of Call Log Data










ID
Channel
Timestamp
Text Message
Keywords




1
Radio
2025-09-01 09:15:00
How do I know if a link is safe?

5

I received a link promising free airtime. Safe?
free, link, scam



A total of 1,280 unique interactions were recorded across all platforms. Radio accounted for 46 percent of engagements, followed by WhatsApp (28 percent), Facebook (17 percent), and SMS (9 percent). ## Keyword Frequency and Word Cloud
Keywords were extracted from the call log to identify the most discussed cybersecurity issues. Table 2 presents the top ten keywords and their frequencies.
Table 2: Frequency of Engagement Keywords

The words phishing, password, and link appeared most frequently, reflecting participants‚Äô interest in safe browsing and online authentication as also visualised in Figure¬†1.








Figure¬†1: Word cloud displaying the frequency of audience engagement keywords related to cybersecurity topics




The resulting word cloud visually highlighted the prominence of key cybersecurity terms. Larger words represented higher engagement levels, with phishing-related queries dominating the discussion.

title: Impact of a Behaviour Change Communication Intervention on Cybersecurity Awareness
text:
Evaluation Design
A quasi-experimental design was used to assess the impact of the intervention. Two groups were compared:

Treatment group: listeners within the radio broadcast coverage areas.
Control group: individuals from areas without access to the campaign.

Knowledge assessments were conducted at baseline and three months after the intervention. Respondents were asked ten questions covering basic cybersecurity practices, and scores were converted to a 0‚Äì100 scale.
The differences-in-differences (DiD) approach was used to estimate the change in knowledge attributable to the campaign. The model took the form:
ùëå ùëñ ùë° = ùõΩ 0 + ùõΩ 1 Treatment ùëñ + ùõΩ 2 Post ùë° + ùõΩ 3 ( Treatment ùëñ √ó Post ùë° ) + ùúñ ùëñ ùë° Y it ‚Äã
where ùëå ùëñ ùë° Y it ‚Äãis the knowledge score for individual ùëñ i at time ùë° t, and ùõΩ 3 Œ≤ 3 ‚Äãcaptures the effect of the intervention.

title: Impact of a Behaviour Change Communication Intervention on Cybersecurity Awareness
text:
Results
A total of 400 participants were included in the treatment group and 400 in the control group. The regression results are presented in Table 3.
Table 3: Differences-in-Differences Regression Results












Variable
Coefficient
Std. Error
z
p-value

5.62



The results show that the treatment √ó post-intervention interaction term is positive and statistically significant (p < 0.001). Participants exposed to the campaign improved their cybersecurity knowledge by an average of 4.25 points more than those in the control group.
The treatment effect at baseline (p = 0.065) indicates minor initial differences between groups, while the post variable (p = 0.022) suggests a small general improvement across both groups over time.

title: Impact of a Behaviour Change Communication Intervention on Cybersecurity Awareness
text:
Interpretation
The findings provide strong evidence that the radio-based BCC intervention improved cybersecurity knowledge. The significant treatment √ó post coefficient confirms that exposure to the campaign led to measurable learning gains. The modest baseline difference supports the comparability of the groups.
A four-point improvement in knowledge represents a meaningful change given the short campaign period. Listeners showed greater awareness of phishing, password safety, and software updates. These findings were reinforced by engagement data, which highlighted frequent discussion of phishing and password topics during radio sessions and online chats.
The results suggest that combining traditional media with interactive digital channels can enhance the effectiveness of public awareness campaigns. Feedback mechanisms such as WhatsApp and Facebook messages allowed audiences to clarify doubts and apply what they learned in real time.

title: Impact of a Behaviour Change Communication Intervention on Cybersecurity Awareness
text:
Conclusion
The behaviour change communication intervention on cybersecurity achieved its objective of increasing awareness among listeners. Radio proved to be an effective medium for disseminating digital safety information, while interactive channels such as WhatsApp and Facebook enhanced engagement and retention.
The differences-in-differences analysis showed that knowledge scores improved significantly among those exposed to the campaign. Word cloud analysis of engagement data revealed that phishing and password security were the most prominent areas of concern.
Continued reinforcement of cybersecurity messages through regular broadcasts, supported by digital media engagement, could help sustain and expand these gains. Future interventions should measure behavioural outcomes, such as the number of phishing reports or password updates, to determine whether improved awareness translates into safer online practices.

title: Community Perceptions of Rainwater Harvesting in Areas Surrounding Mzuzu City, Malawi
text: Rainwater harvesting (RWH) is increasingly recognised as an important strategy for improving household water security. Understanding how communities perceive RWH can help in promoting its adoption and ensuring the sustainability of such initiatives.

title: Community Perceptions of Rainwater Harvesting in Areas Surrounding Mzuzu City, Malawi
text: Rainwater harvesting (RWH) is increasingly recognised as an important strategy for improving household water security. Understanding how communities perceive RWH can help in promoting its adoption and ensuring the sustainability of such initiatives.

title: Community Perceptions of Rainwater Harvesting in Areas Surrounding Mzuzu City, Malawi
text:
Objective
This study explored perceptions of rainwater harvesting among households located in three peri-urban areas surrounding Mzuzu City, Malawi. The main objective was to assess community attitudes towards RWH and identify demographic factors associated with positive or negative perceptions.

title: Community Perceptions of Rainwater Harvesting in Areas Surrounding Mzuzu City, Malawi
text:
Methodology
A cross-sectional survey was conducted among 120 respondents selected through systematic random sampling. The questionnaire captured data on household demographics (age, gender, education, income) and perception scores regarding rainwater harvesting, measured using a 5-point Likert scale (1 = strongly disagree to 5 = strongly agree).

title: Community Perceptions of Rainwater Harvesting in Areas Surrounding Mzuzu City, Malawi
text:
Analysis
Perception scores were dichotomised into positive and negative categories. Associations between demographic characteristics and perceptions were tested using chi-square analysis.
A logistic regression model was then used to estimate adjusted odds ratios (AORs) and 95% confidence intervals (CIs) for factors associated with positive perceptions of RWH.
The results are presented in Table 1.
Table 1. Association between demographic factors and positive perception of rainwater harvesting among peri-urban households around Mzuzu City (n = 120)

title: Community Perceptions of Rainwater Harvesting in Areas Surrounding Mzuzu City, Malawi
text:
Interpretation
Respondents with secondary and tertiary education were significantly more likely to have positive perceptions of rainwater harvesting compared to those with primary education (p < 0.05). Similarly, households with higher monthly income (>MWK 100,000) showed greater likelihood of supporting RWH initiatives. Gender and age were not significantly associated with perceptions.
These findings suggest that educational exposure and economic capacity play key roles in shaping positive attitudes toward rainwater harvesting practices in peri-urban Mzuzu.

title: Community Perceptions of Rainwater Harvesting in Areas Surrounding Mzuzu City, Malawi
text:
Conclusion
The study found that better-educated and higher-income households were more receptive to adopting rainwater harvesting systems. Future awareness campaigns should target less-educated and lower-income groups, focusing on the affordability and long-term benefits of household water collection.

title: Study on Menstrual Hygiene Management Interventions in Three Communities of Malawi
text:
Visualise how menstrual hygiene materials are disposed of in three communities.
Focus on the flow from materials used to disposal methods using a Sankey diagram.

title: Study on Menstrual Hygiene Management Interventions in Three Communities of Malawi
text:
Visualise how menstrual hygiene materials are disposed of in three communities.
Focus on the flow from materials used to disposal methods using a Sankey diagram.

title: Study on Menstrual Hygiene Management Interventions in Three Communities of Malawi
text:
Method

Cross-sectional survey of 200 menstruating individuals across three communities.
Collected data on materials used: Pads, Cloth, Tampons, Cups, Others.
Collected data on disposal methods: Bins, Pits, Burning, Flushing, Reuse, Composting.
Tabulated the number of users flowing from each material to each disposal method.
Visualised flows using a Sankey diagram to identify dominant disposal pathways.

title: Study on Menstrual Hygiene Management Interventions in Three Communities of Malawi
text:
Results
Below is the Sankey diagram illustrating the flow from menstrual hygiene materials to disposal methods.








Figure¬†1: Sankey Diagram of Material Flow




Explanation of flows (fake data example):

Pads: 80 users dispose in bins, 30 in pits, 10 by burning.
Cloth: 50 users dispose by reuse, 20 via composting.
Tampons: 15 users burn, 5 flush.
Cups: 10 users compost, 8 reuse.
Other absorbents: 5 dispose in bins, 3 in pits.

The diagram highlights the dominant disposal routes for each material.

title: Study on Menstrual Hygiene Management Interventions in Three Communities of Malawi
text:
Interpretation

Bins are the primary disposal method for pads and other absorbents
Reuse is common for cloth and cups, suggesting a potential for hygiene education and resource efficiency.
Burning and flushing are minor but present, indicating environmental risks
Composting is rare, suggesting opportunities for sustainable disposal interventions
Sankey visualisation effectively shows which materials contribute most to each disposal method, guiding intervention planning.

title: Study on Menstrual Hygiene Management Interventions in Three Communities of Malawi
text:
Conclusion

Pads are the most commonly disposed material, primarily in bins
Cloth and cups tend to be reused, indicating potential for education on safe washing practices.
Interventions could focus on reducing unsafe disposal (burning, flushing) and promoting sustainable options (composting)
The Sankey diagram helps stakeholders visually understand disposal flows, informing targeted MHM interventions.

title: Estimation of Sludge Accumulation and Emptying Needs in On-Site Sanitation Systems: A Predictive Modelling Approach
text:
Urban areas in low- and middle-income countries rely heavily on on-site sanitation systems such as pit latrines. As cities expand, managing faecal sludge becomes a key challenge for urban authorities.
This study quantified sludge volumes from sampled pits and modelled the rates of filling and emptying needs over time. Understanding how much sludge accumulates each year is essential for planning collection and treatment capacity at city level.

title: Estimation of Sludge Accumulation and Emptying Needs in On-Site Sanitation Systems: A Predictive Modelling Approach
text:
Urban areas in low- and middle-income countries rely heavily on on-site sanitation systems such as pit latrines. As cities expand, managing faecal sludge becomes a key challenge for urban authorities.
This study quantified sludge volumes from sampled pits and modelled the rates of filling and emptying needs over time. Understanding how much sludge accumulates each year is essential for planning collection and treatment capacity at city level.

title: Estimation of Sludge Accumulation and Emptying Needs in On-Site Sanitation Systems: A Predictive Modelling Approach
text:
Goal
To estimate the yearly sludge volumes requiring emptying over an 8-year projection period, comparing pits of circular and rectangular shapes.

title: Estimation of Sludge Accumulation and Emptying Needs in On-Site Sanitation Systems: A Predictive Modelling Approach
text:
Methods
Two datasets were collected in parallel:

Field measurements: Sludge depth and pit dimensions were used to calculate total and remaining pit volumes.
Household survey: Gathered demographic data including household size and toilet usage frequency.

The sludge accumulation rate was modelled based on the remaining pit space (0.5 m below the drop hole), using literature-based estimates of faecal sludge generation.
Yearly volumes requiring emptying were simulated for 8 years under both pit shapes:

Circular pits: ùëâ = ùúã ùëü 2 ‚Ñé V=œÄr 2 h
Rectangular pits: ùëâ = ùëô √ó ùë§ √ó ‚Ñé V=l√ów√óh

Modelled data were visualised using R‚Äôs ggplot2, showing the decline in emptying needs as pits reach capacity (Figure¬†1)











(a) The solid lines show the proportion of households requiring pit emptying each year, while the dashed lines represent the mean sludge volume.






Figure¬†1: Projected annual trends in sludge volume and pit emptying needs by latrine type over an eight-year period.

title: Estimation of Sludge Accumulation and Emptying Needs in On-Site Sanitation Systems: A Predictive Modelling Approach
text:
Interpretation

The dual-axis plot shows that as years progress, both sludge volume and the proportion of pits requiring emptying decrease steadily.
Circular pits initially produced slightly higher volumes, but the difference between pit types diminished over time.
The pattern indicates that annual emptying programmes reduce long-term accumulation, allowing cities to plan realistic treatment capacity.
The decline is gradual, not abrupt, suggesting consistent maintenance rather than one-time emptying.
One key limitation is that the projections did not include future population growth as estimated by the National Statistics Office, which may increase total sludge volume in subsequent years.

title: Privacy Policy
text:
We take privacy seriously and ensure that all personal and sensitive information is handled responsibly. This policy explains how we collect, use, and protect data in a way that is clear and transparent for our clients. Our commitments include:

We only request for data that is necessary for providing our services.
Personal or sensitive information is never shared with third parties without your consent.
Data is stored securely using strong technical measures.
Clients have full control over their information and can request access, updates, or deletion at any time.
Our practices comply with all relevant privacy laws to ensure your rights are protected.
